name: Dec 21 or 23 Sew Sweet Little Mice with Ms. June Camp
description:
Choose from two dates:
Saturday, 1-4pm, Dec 21
OR Monday, 9am-12pm, Dec 23
$40
Includes supplies & snack
Ages 4 & up (age 2-3 welcome with parent)

June Covington leads this charming hand-stitched craft. Learn how to thread a needle, tie knots, and whip stitch to a fashion festive little mouse or several meece, perfect for sneaking into stockings or teasing frisky kittens. Enjoy a cozy day in the studio to get into the holiday season! Parents with toddlers, adults and teens welcome, camp designed for ages 4-12.

name: Dec 23 Glimmer, Sparkle, Twinkle Camp with Ms. Emily!!!
description:
Monday, December 23, 1-4pm, ages 4 and up

Create a mixed media still life drawing inspired by the glimmer, sparkle and twinkle of  holiday lights. Learn to layer color on a contrasting dark paper, explore linear movement of the winding cords, and make bright geometric renderings of colored lights. 

Welcome home for the holidays, Ms. Emily Riggert!

name: Spring Teen Drawing & Portfolio Prep Class
description:
Spring Session is January 8-May 21, 19 classes
Wednesdays, 5:30-7pm
Instructor: Kyle Hobratschk
Price: $380 (tuition) + $60 (supplies)

Take advantage of our Early Bird Registration period...
Code EARLY 25 gets you 25% off before Dec 1.
Code EARLY10 gets you 10% off before Jan 1. Don't miss out!

Work with our resident artist, Kyle Hobratschk, to learn the power of observation in developing your drawing skills and a series of original works in your portfolio. Students will have the opportunity to work in several sophisticated art mediums, as well as access to the printmaking studio and press. The semester ends with a one-on-one portfolio review and group exhibition.

This class is excellent for preparing your portfolio for auditions for high school or college, or for anyone truly committed to making art. Scholarship assistance available with teacher recommendation and demonstration of need or volunteer commitment. Contact info@oilandcotton.com for more information or to sponsor a teen.

name: Spring Age 7-14 Art Class
description:
Join us for a weekly class this spring.
SPRING SESSION IS JAN 4-MAY 23
*no classes held May 10-15.
EARLY REGISTRATION DISCOUNT PERIOD:

SAVE 10% BEFORE JANUARY 1. Enter code EARLY10.

Instructors: Jessica Sinks & June Covington.

Choose your day & time in the drop down menu.

Students learn about historical relevance and creative possibilities through a combination of structured learning and independent thinking. While developing their technical skills, students experience working in the styles of artists and art movements from ancient history to present day. Students keep a sketchbook for original ideas and observational drawings.

The session will end with an independent project, allowing students to assimilate what they have learned into an original project in their chosen medium. Select works will be exhibited in our annual student show in May.

• Start anytime
• 1-hour weekly class
• Small class size
• $25 drawing kit required. Remaining supplies provided.

Our signature program, students enrolled in this weekly class are eligible to attend the Drawing Club FREE on Tuesdays 5:30-6:30pm (yes, you CAN take the 4:30 class for a two-hour drop off).

name: Spring Age 3-6 Art Class
description:
Join us for a weekly class this spring.
SPRING SESSION IS JAN 4-MAY 23
*no classes held May 10-15.
EARLY REGISTRATION DISCOUNT PERIOD:

SAVE 10% BEFORE JANUARY 1. Enter code EARLY10.

Instructors: Shannon Driscoll, Kayli House Cusick & June Covington.

Choose your day & time in the drop down menu.

Explore a variety of art-making materials and concepts, while learning about artists from history. Students will get to use different media each week, including tempera, acrylic and watercolor paints, graphite, charcoal, ink, soft and oil pastel, and various clays. All supplies included. This spring, we will learn about history & time, going all the way back to Cave Art, Ancient Egypt, Greek, Roman & Medieval Times!

Students are exposed to specific vocabulary and broad concepts. Take home practice sheets provide information for parents, who are encouraged to continue and reinforce the learning with art-making at home, using art terms to get specific about their creative works, and by visiting our local museums together as a family.

• Start anytime
• 1-hour weekly class
• Small class size
• All supplies included

name: Spring Age 2-3 Art Class
description:
Join us for a weekly class this spring.
SPRING SESSION IS JAN 4-MAY 23
*no classes held May 10-15.
EARLY REGISTRATION DISCOUNT PERIOD:

SAVE 10% BEFORE JANUARY 1. Enter code EARLY10.

Instructors: Shannon Driscoll, Kayli House Cusick & June Covington

Choose your day & time in the drop down menu. 

Join us for a fun art experience and weekly class for your toddler. We will integrate fun holiday crafts with learning about how artists use the elements of art: line, shape, color, texture & value. This class is ongoing, and parents are encouraged to continue in summer & fall.

This class is for parent & child together, allowing your child to build self-esteem and motor skills while warming up to the art studio. Once students are comfortable (and potty trained), they are welcome to join the weekly Young Artists class, where parents can drop off for the hour.

name: Homeschool Art Class
description:
Now available for the whole family. Preschool art class will run  while the older siblings have class. 

Pre-Schoolers (age 3-5)
Schoolers (age 5-15)

Explore artists and art history through the ages. Students learn art elements, principles, techniques and terms as they study great art to inspire the creation of finished projects, study pieces, and independent work. Various technical skills and art materials are used in the studio, including charcoal, ink, paint, pastel, wire, wood, clay, and more. 

Parents can drop off (age 5-15) or observe and are invited to participate in constructive critiques for continued learning at home.

Our homeschool program is also available off-site, privately and semi-privately. Please call Kayli to schedule. 214-942-0474

name: Spring Age 8-18 Sewing Classes with Jesse Bartlett
description:
Instructor: Jesse Bartlett
Tuesdays 4:00-5:30 - Beginners, age 8-18
Tuesdays 5:30-7:00 - Intermediate, age 10-18

Weekly machine sewing class. 
Beginner project fabric provided. Intermediate returning students provide own fabrics for specialized projects. 
Bring your own machine, or rent one for $5/class.

Class Description:
Learn to sew on your machine and make functional and wearable art, a new project each month! Returning intermediate students work towards individual projects, apparel and home dec.

About the Instructor:
Jesse Bartlett is a professional seamstress and art teacher from Oak Cliff, Texas. Learn more about her at www.sewjesse.com.

Tuition Options: 
Monthly - $125
Spring Semester Special - $475 (you know you love her, put a ring on it and save $125 when you register for January 7-May 20 all in one payment).

options.name: March 4, 18, 25, April 1 Lunch Bag & Pencil Case

name: Jan 16-Mar 6 Printmaking | Essential Copper Plate Processes for the Press
description:
Thursdays, 6:30-9:00pm
Instructor: Kyle Hobratschk

This eight-week course will teach the essentials to printmaking from copper plates, a medium rooted in five hundred years of history. The first week will familiarize students with the press as they create monotypes from pattern rich still life arrangements. The second and third week will cover techniques for dry point with monotype applications, and weeks four through eight will concentrate on the etching process. Historical contexts with artists ranging from Rembrandt and Goya to Whistler and Hopper will complement class time. Still life materials will be available each week, although students are invited to bring objects of their own liking, or work from existing drawings and photographs. It is also recommended that students save time for some drawing work at home throughout the workshop’s duration.

The printmaking studio will be available for extended work one hour after each two-hour class. This workshop will use a floor model American French Tool Etching Press: plate bed 24” x 48”, and print shop equipped with a ferric chloride acid bath, asphaltum station, aquatint chamber, and heated inking station.

Student should have a strong interest in drawing.
$45 supply fee includes:
- copper plates covering a sum 160 square inches
- etching needle
- burnisher
- printmaking ink, Tarleton, gloves, newsprint
- miscellaneous materials supplied in print shop
- paper available at nominal costs
www.kylehobratschk.com

name: Jan 11 Bulb Basket
description:
Saturday, January 11, 10-4pm
Instructor: Jan Schmidt 

Students will learn an open weave pattern and make a functional bulb basket in one class day. The basket is woven in the round in your lap and takes on a beautiful organic shape.  This is a wonderful beginning level basket weaving class, all levels are welcome.

The basket begins by making a star pattern of reeds that are held in place with a weight. Then a small thin reed is woven around and around to form the bulbous body of the basket. A pretty leather strap is added so that the basket can hang from a door knob or hook.

name: Jan 17 How Not To Be Intimidated by Poetry Part 4: Form, Informality and Shapeliness
description:
Friday, January 17, 6:30-9pm
Instructor: Joe Milazzo

How Not To Be Intimidated By Poetry (and Perhaps Write Some of Your Own) 
Part 4: Form, Informality and Shapeliness


In this beginner-level workshop, we will work together to demystify the various ways in which poets -- and poems -- create an aesthetic experience via careful, imaginative manipulations of language. We will read aloud individual poems by a diverse array of poets and discuss the various elements of poetic expression and how those elements make meaning. We will concentrate especially on the sensual or perceptible rather than cerebral qualities of each poem. 

Part 1:
We will examine the poem's arrangement or "body" on the page.  

Part 2:
We will listen for the manner in which the poem sounds itself out, making both noise and music

Part 3:
We will reverse engineer those words and phrases that serve as devices for activating images, emotions and ideas within the poem. In 

Part 4: 
We will learn about the poem as a special class of saying, one that offers the reader entry into traditions of communication as well as expression. 

During each session, we will apply what we have gleaned from our collective reading to a series of short creative writing exercises designed to encourage further appreciation of poetic language as an artistic medium.

About the instructor: Joe Milazzo is a writer, editor, publisher, educator and designer. He holds an MFA in Writing from the California Institute of the Arts. He has published published poetry, fiction and essays in a wide variety of publications, including The Dallas Morning News, Drunken Boat, The Collagist, Antennae and Black Clock. You can learn more about Joe, his teaching, his publications and his current activities by visiting http://www.slowstudies.net/jmilazzo.

Joe has designed a series of writing workshops for Oil and Cotton students. You are welcome to pick and choose or take the entire series.

Sept 20, 6:30-8:30pm How Not To Be Intimidated-Seeing Poetry 
Oct 18, 6:30-8:30pm How Not To Be Intimidated-Hearing Poetry
Nov 15, 6:30-9pm How Not To Be Intimidated-Simile, Metaphor, and Figurative Language
Jan 17, 6:30-9pm How Not To Be Intimidated-Form, Informality and Shapeliness

name: Jan 18 Knotted Netting with Analise Minjarez
description:
Saturday, January 18, 1-3pm
Instructor: Analise Minjarez 

Netting has been a part of human history for thousands of years, since we learned how to spin fiber into string about 50,000 years ago. It likely started with simple looped netting, in which the string was simply pulled through the loops of the previous row (this technique is also thought to be a precursor of knitting),but knots soon proved to be a far more stable and secure way to make nets. 

In this class students will learn simple knotted netting technique using a variety of natural and synthetic fibers to make several net samples.

name: Jan 20 MLK Day Camp
description:
Monday, January 20, 9am-12pm
Instructor: Kayli House Cusick

Celebrate Dr. Martin Luther King and pay tribute to his work and wisdom through art. We will sift through our collection of collage material to create text-based works inspired by Dr. King's famous speeches.

We will also get into font design and typography, a favorite skill of budding writers! We will create our own fonts, work with vintage Letraset rub-off lettering, stencils and stamps.

Ages 4 to teens

name: Jan 20 Draw-a-thon Camp
description:
Monday, Jan 20, 1-4pm
Instructor: Jessica Sinks

Join us for an afternoon of sketching and drawing with Ms. Jessica, president of the Oil and Cotton Drawing Club. We will study forms, learn about value and shading with various marks, and experiment with dry drawing mediums. Learn some new skills to apply to your favorite subjects - animals, cars, people, toilets, or whatever piques your interest!

For ages 6+

name: Jan 25 Miniature Navajo Rug with June Covington
description:
Saturday, January 25, 2014, 12:30pm – 4:30pm
Instructor: June Covington

In this introductory class students will begin a miniature (6"x9") Navajo rug on a wooden frame-loom using traditional methods and materials. Students will learn terms and skills used in frame-loom weaving. Churro wool will be used to weave on the frame with a yarn weft and cotton warp. Weaving tools including shuttles, beaters, yarn needles, tensioner devices and heddles will be used.

Students will explore tapestry weave, warp faced-weaving, plain weave and learn tensioning, joining, tying-up, warping the loom, planning the design. Traditional patterns using symbols from nature and history will inform our weaving and spiritual aspects of geometric shapes (all a part of planning the weaving) will be discussed.

name: Jan 26-March 2 Screenprinting Series with Betty Rodriguez
description:
Winter-Spring 2014
Sundays, 2-4:30pm
Instructor: Betty Rodriguez 

This six-week workshop will provide an in depth understanding of the silk screening process. Students will build their own press and learn everything they need to know to silkscreen within their own home. Students will complete two silkscreen projects and work with multiple colors. Each student will receive an 18 page workbook filled with information and tips for continued printing after class! Our talented and fun teacher explores aspects of both commercial printing and studio art practice. See more images from our last class on our Facebook page.

name: Feb 8 Introduction to Embroidery with Stephanie Johnson
description:
Saturday, February 8, 11-1:30pm
Instructor: Stephanie Johnson

Join us for this introduction to the delicate wonders of embroidery. Students will begin their very own embroidery stitch sampler. The sampler will be made by following a pattern.

Topics include basic skills of choosing and preparing the fabric, using the hoop, and threading the needle, transfer techniques, anchoring stitches (to knot or plunge), to finishing the project for final display. Eight traditional embroidery stitches will be taught: Running stitch (blue), Backstitch (blue), Split stitch (green), Feather stitch (lime green), Backstitch variation (orange and pink), French Knots (red), Chain stitch (light purple), Blanket stitch (purple). With the skills learned, you will be able to continue making beautiful pieces of art or simply embellish items of your own. Visit our website to register online.

Materials Included
• 6" embroidery hoop
• white cotton fabric
• floss of varying colors
• crewel needles
• transfer paper
• sample pattern

name: Feb 9 Woven Altars with Sarah Westrup
description:
Sunday, February 9, 11-1pm
Instructor: Sarah Westrup

Students will learn how to transform a simple box into a functioning loom and weave a space for memory. Utilize an assemblage of materials such as textiles, paper, photos, and cherished treasures to construct meaning within your own personal shrine. Found objects such as grasses, yucca pods, cactus needles, and tumble weeds will be incorporated into your altar so you can take a little piece of Texas home with you. Participants will explore the process of creating layers with simple woven structures and collage natural and man made materials. Folks are welcomed to bring any items or images they would like to incorporate into their shrine or choose from an array of provided materials. The altars would make a lovely gift for Valentine's Day, Mother's Day or as way to honor yourself or those dear to you.

Visit www.sunbeamoperations.sqsp.com to learn more about the instructor, Sarah Westrup.

name: Feb 15 Bicycle Basket
description:
Saturday, February 15, 10-4pm
Instructor: Jan Schmidt

This sweet bike basket can hold a lot of weight with its solid ash wood bottom. Learn all the basic weaves and shaping using rattan reed and seagrass. Finish it off with leather straps and a sturdy metal handle so you can take your basket with you. 

Jan has developed a series of classes for Oil and Cotton that will be taught monthly. Look for more Basket classes throughout 2014.

name: Feb 17 President's Day Art Camp
description:
Presidential profiles: past, present & future.
Kids Art Camp for ages 4-12
$40 includes snack & all supplies


Choose a favorite president to learn about, creating an historical silhouette paper cut. Then use your new art skill to explore your own potential. Use your own profile line to make an inspirational self-portrait. Keep it presidential, or go way out Picasso.

name: Fall Age 2-3 Weekly Art Class
description:
Join us for a weekly class this fall.
Fall session runs now til December 22*.
*no classes held November 26-30.
START ANYTIME - Tuition is prorated each week.

Instructors: Jesse Bartlett & June Covington

Choose your day & time in the drop down menu. Monthly tuition is also available at $75/month or drop in for on class for $20. Please call to schedule monthly or drop in. 214-942-0474

Join us for a fun art experience and weekly class for your toddler. We will integrate fun holiday crafts with learning about how artists use the elements of art: line, shape, color, texture & value. This class is ongoing, and parents are encouraged to continue in the spring session.

This class is for parent & child together, allowing your child to build self-esteem and motor skills while warming up to the art studio. Once students are comfortable (and potty trained), they are welcome to join the weekly Young Artists class, where parents can drop off for the hour.

name: Feb 22 Polaroid Transfers with Laura Barth Turner
description:
Saturday, February 22, 12-4pm
Instructor: Laura Barth Turner

Back by popular demand, we will be delving into the craftier, more DIY side of photography with Polaroid Transfers.

We all (well, a lot of us) remember using polaroids back in the old days- but unless you were a professional photographer, you were probably just shooting pictures, shaking them to develop them, and enjoying the instant results.

In this class we will take the process a step further, making a transfer of the image onto fine art paper to create an original artwork.

Polaroid transfers use a larger version of polaroid film, and actually pull the emulsion (the picture itself) off of its backing to transfer it onto a new surface. This can be done onto watercolor, canvas, or many other surfaces. It is loads of fun, very hands on, and always produces surprising and interesting results.

All materials included- film, paper, and a camera to borrow in class. Each student will make 10 pictures which they will then transfer onto paper to take home with them.

name: Feb 22-23 Painting: Retro Portraiture with Anna Membrino
description:
Painting Weekender:
February 22-23
Saturday 10am-4pm & Sunday 1-4pm
Instructor: Anna Membrino
Price: $175 (includes discounted take home supply kit)

Paint a series of portraits of your relatives based on old family photographs. The high contrast, low
resolution quality of photographs taken before the advent of high quality digital images lends itself to
creating paintings that are simplified and stylish.

Students create several drawings and small paintings of their selected photographs. Working from these
studies each student will then paint one large portrait of a cherished family member from a past era.

Each student will receive a kit which contains:
two 8"x10" canvas panels
one 12"x16" cradled wood panel
a 6-color set of M. Graham acrylic paints
Protege brush set

Please bring a selection of at least six old photographs to the first class. Photographs from 1930’s, 40’s, or 50’s work very well for this project. However, any older family photographs can be used.

Anna Membrino recently graduated with her MFA in Painting from Southern Methodist University. She currently paints abstracted still lifes and lives in the Dallas area. Before beginning her current body of
work Anna spent many years studying the family histories and untold stories that that were hidden in the hundreds of photographs taken by her grandparents throughout the 1930’s , 40’s, and 50’s .

name: Feb 28 DROP IN & Make Your Mardi Gras Mask
description:
Drop in between 3-6pm on Friday, Feb 28.
All ages (parents stay with kids)
$25 advance, $35 at the door

Materials will be out and our studio will be ready for you to make the most awesome leather mask and be the envy of all your neighbors. We will provide inspiration and guidance to the creatively challenged.

Advanced registration is CHEAPER than showing up unannounced, throwing a bone to you kindred type A's out there.

name: Feb 28 Memory Jugs with Bruce Lee Webb
description:
Friday, February 28, 6:30-9pm
Memory Jugs with Bruce Lee Webb

n this workshop students will learn the history and origin of the folk art tradition of making Memory Jugs. Bruce, owner of the amazing Webb Gallery in Waxahachie, began collecting and researching Memory jugs 25 years ago, finding the curious crazy textures and tactile qualities alluring.

Memory Jugs were made in many cultures, but in Victorian times, when amplified mourning traditions took root, they became a folk art phenomenon. Memory jugs were often found in Victorian parlors along side hair weavings in shadow boxes. In African American cemeteries in the Southern United States, examples have been found on graves. Some jugs had a hole made in the jug to render it useless and to "release the spirit from haunting the jug" which was then covered with various small articles of a loved one. A memory jug empties Grandpas trinket drawer and elevates the myriad of objects to art for the fireplace mantel. They are objects of sentimentality with the power to evoke memories.

In the workshop students will be provided "borrowed memories" and will work on a Mason jar. Bruce will provide each student with a mason jar, plaster putty, paint and trinkets and pottery shards for their memory jar. Students are encouraged to bring their own jug or other item they want to cover as well as any memorable items for their jar.

www.webbartgallery.com

name: Fall Age 4-6 Weekly Art Class
description:
Join us for a weekly class this fall.
Fall session is now til December 22*.
*no classes held November 26-30.
START ANYTIME - Tuition is prorated weekly to reflect the semester length.
Instructors: Shannon Driscoll, June Covington, &  Jessica Sinks

Choose your day & time in the drop down menu. Choose your day & time in the drop down menu. Monthly tuition is also available. Please call to schedule monthly. 214-942-0474

Explore a variety of art-making materials and concepts, while learning about artists from history. Students will get to use different media each week, including tempera, acrylic and watercolor paints, graphite, charcoal, ink, soft and oil pastel, and various clays. All supplies included. This fall, we will look at art around the world, learning about traditional and contemporary art of Mexico, Africa, and Asia.

Students are exposed to specific vocabulary and broad concepts. Take home practice sheets provide information for parents, who are encouraged to continue and reinforce the learning with art-making at home, using art terms to get specific about their creative works, and by visiting our local museums together as a family.

• Start anytime
• 1-hour weekly class
• Small class size
• All supplies included

name: Fall Age 7-14 Weekly Art Class
description:
Join us for a weekly class this fall.

Fall session is September 3 through December 22*.
*no classes held November 26-30.
Instructor: Jessica Sinks, June Covington, Shannon Driscoll

Choose your day & time in the drop down menu. Choose your day & time in the drop down menu. Monthly tuition is also available. Please call to schedule monthly. 214-942-0474

Students learn about historical relevance and creative possibilities through a combination of structured learning and independent thinking. While developing their technical skills, students experience working in the styles of artists and art movements from ancient history to present day. Students keep a sketchbook for original ideas and observational drawings. This fall, we will get inspiration from Texas artists Melissa Miller and Robert Rauschenberg as well as historical favorites Pablo Picasso, Joan Miro & Alexander Calder. 

The session will end with an independent project, allowing students to assimilate what they have learned into an original project in their chosen medium.

• Start anytime
• 1-hour weekly class
• Small class size
• $25 drawing kit required. Remaining supplies provided.

Our signature program, students enrolled in this weekly class are eligible to attend the Drawing Club FREE on Tuesdays 5:30-6:30pm (savvy moms take the 4:30 class for a two-hour drop off).

name: Scholarship Contribution
description: Help support our scholarship program, providing weekly art classes to Oak Cliff kids. Our students learn about art history and the language and techniques of visual expression. Small classes, professional teachers, and a supportive environment give kids a safe space to confidently manifest their individual talents and unique ideas.

name: Mar 1 Natural Dye with Sarah Westrup
description:
Saturday, March 1, 1-4pm
Instructor: Sarah Westrup

In this introductory class you will experiment with dying silk and cotton in a range of natural dye baths using material such as; black beans, hibiscus flowers, avocado pits, and more.  Unlike synthetic dyes, natural dyes are a living thing. The colors produced are very complex and harmonize together. Each color holds hints of other colors within it. This produces vibrations in the natural dye color that synthetic dyes could never have. 

There is so much wonder in the fact that every naturally dyed piece of cloth is unique. Come experience the spontaneity and beauty of the colors produced with natural dyes with instructor Sarah Westrup. 

Participant will create a dye notebook, leave with swatches and dye recipes to take home to use as a reference for future natural dyeing adventures.

name: March 2 Introduction to Leatherworking with Scott Horn
description:
Sunday, March 2, 11-2pm
Instructor: Scott Horn

Learn the basics of leatherworking – one of humankind’s oldest art forms. This class will teach the techniques to cut, tool, and dye raw leather in a style whose modern day roots are right here in Texas. Students will learn to create a cuff bracelet or coaster in this introductory class. Pattern making and pictorial carving will be demonstrated. Patterns will be available, or you can create your own from scratch. All students will receive a tool kit that they can take home to continue leatherworking. Scott's classes tend to fill quickly, early registration is recommended.

As a child Scott Horn learned the basics of leatherwork from his grandfather Milton Horn, a Master of the craft. In 2010 Scott inherited his grandfather’s tools and shifted away from sculpture to focus on reviving this dying art form for the 21st century.

Take home kit includes:
Leather
Mallet
Bordering Stamp
Veiner Stamp
Basket Weave Stamp
Seeder Stamp

name: Mar 10-14 Spring Break Morning: Ruckus Red Grooms
description:
One of the pivotal moments in my life as an art lover was visiting Red Groom's Ruckus Rodeo installation at the Fort Worth Modern in the early 90s. Here was an art explosion, way cooler than that cool store at the mall by the same name.

In this 5-day art camp, kids will get to know Red Grooms and his character Ruckus, creating their own roomful of art in similar mixed media. We will make pop-up study books and collaborate to create a veritable visual pandemonium of their own design. They will sculpt, paint, and go art nuts. I hope they will remember it!

March 10-14, 2014
Mon-Fri, 9am-12pm
Drop-in Mon-Thur per diem available
For ages 5 to teens

name: Mar 10-14 Spring Break Afternoon: Calder's Circus
description:
So, besides for taking figure drawing with my mom at Club Dada in the 80s, another moment that made a lasting impression was encountering Calder's Circus in the basement of the Whitney (not the Alamo). 

This camp will allow kids to exercise their artistic and scientific brains as they engineer mobile and stabile circus characters from wire and mixed sculptural materials. They will be true bricoleurs, tinkering and figuring out how to create their characters from bits of wire, fabric, and other found materials. Together, we will create a functioning circus to be performed on Friday, complete with sound effects.

Mar 10-14
Mon-Fri, 1-4pm
For ages 5-12, $150 week
Per diem available Mon-Thur

name: March 22 Rainbow Basket
description:
Saturday, March 22, 10-4pm
Instructor: Jan Schmidt

Jan Schmidt will once again lead Oil and Cotton students through the magical process of weaving loose reeds into a beautiful and functional art objects. Jan has built a following of students due to her expertise and ability to communicate her craft to others. Don't miss the opportunity to spend a day with new friends and learn the art of basket weaving.

This basket is constructed around a swing D-handle. It’s a fun beginner basket because it has a lot of color and basic techniques are used such as start/stop rows, twining, rimming and shaping. Jan developed this pattern when she ended up with a lot of scrap color left from other baskets. Beginners welcome.

name: March 29 Marbling Paper and Fabric
description:
Saturday, March 29, 10am-12pm
Instructor: Shannon Driscoll

Marbling is an ancient technique used to embellish paper and fabric with swirls of color. This is a fun class that allows students to be creative without needing art experience. Colors are floated on a gel-like bath and transferred to paper and fabric surfaces.

Students will learn:
-chemistry and how to coat papers and surface with an alum mordant -how to make a Carrageenan size -how mix and test a variety of paints with gall -to make a splatter brush and other marbling tools from house hold items -how to manipulate the floating paints to create magical patterns of color Leave class with at least 10 sheets of marbled paper and 2 fabric samples.

name: Apr 12 Cyanotypes with Laura Barth Turner
description:
Saturday, April 12 1-3pm
Instructor: Laura Barth Turner
 
Our workshop will introduce students to the history of the cyanotype process. Students will learn how to make sensitizing solutions and coat various natural fibered fabrics and papers. Photograms will be created with botanical specimens, feathers, lace, and other objects (no film, camera, or negatives needed). Students interested in experimenting with negatives or glass plate negatives should contact us before class. A large portion of the class will take place outside, as sunlight will be used to expose the cyanotypes.

Because the small class sizes, this workshop is adaptable for participants of all ages and levels of experience. There will be lots of one-on-one coaching. See examples of Cyanotypes here and here.

name: Apr 18 Cascarones Easter Camp
description:
Friday, April 18, 9am-12pm
School's Out Camp for ages 4 to 12 (teens & adults welcome)

MAKE YOUR OWN CASCARONES

Get ready for Easter weekend by making your own cascarones! Dye, decorate, fill, seal & BUST ON SOMEONE'S HEAD (at home)!

name: Apr 18 Bluebonnet Painting
description:
Friday, April 18, 1-4pm
School's Out Art Camp for ages 4-12
PAINTING
$40

Learn all about blue, green, and the Lupinus texensis...the Texas Bluebonnet! We will mix colors and values and use all parts of the paintbrush to create a lovely spring study on 8x10 canvas. Heck, we might even dress up in our khakis and take a class portrait.

TOTALLY FUN!

name: April 19 New England Tote
description:
Saturday, April 19, 10-4pm
Instructor: Jan Schmidt

Master weaver Jan Schmidt will take you through the "ins and outs" of weaving your very own basket from start to finish. Tote everything from groceries to books. This is a very strong basket using shaker tape that wraps all the way around the bottom. Shaping is most important in the weaving of this basket. A variety of colors will be available.

name: Apr 21 Earth Day Eve Day
description:
Monday, April 21, 9am-12pm
School's Out Art Camp for ages 4-12 (teens & adults welcome)
SCULPTURE

Did someone say repurpose? Did someone say repurpose?

Get into our plethora of donated goodies to make something surprising. Kids will discover new functions for "trash," learning to engineer and design a series of sculptures.

name: Apr 26 Painting with Natural Dyes: Cochineal
description:
Saturday, April 26, 12:30 - 4:30pm
Instructor: Sarah Westrup

In this class students will learn the magic of dyeing with the most precious insect in Mexico called, cochineal. Historically, cochineal was used to achieve the most luscious of reds, pinks, and purples on cloth. It has a high lightfastness and can achieve an array of cool and warm tones Participants will explore the process of preparing dried cochineal bugs for dyeing and will learn how to create painted patterns on tannined and un-tannined silk and cotton using thickened mordants. This class is geared to beginners who are looking to dive right into the world of natural dyes!

Visit www.sunbeamoperations.squarespace.com to learn more about the instructor, Sarah Westrup!

name: April 26 Miniature Navajo Rug with June Covington
description:
Saturday, April 26, 2014, 12:30pm – 4:30pm
Instructor: June Covington

In this introductory class students will begin a miniature (6"x9") Navajo rug on a wooden frame-loom using traditional methods and materials. Students will learn terms and skills used in frame-loom weaving. Churro wool will be used to weave on the frame with a yarn weft and cotton warp. Weaving tools including shuttles, beaters, yarn needles, tensioner devices and heddles will be used.

Students will explore tapestry weave, warp faced-weaving, plain weave and learn tensioning, joining, tying-up, warping the loom, planning the design. Traditional patterns using symbols from nature and history will inform our weaving and spiritual aspects of geometric shapes (all a part of planning the weaving) will be discussed.

Students may keep the loom for an additional $15. You can decide at the end of class:)

name: May 10 Algonquin Basket
description:
Saturday, May 10, 10-4pm
Instructor: Jan Schmidt

This is a large sturdy basket that can be used for laundry or newspapers (16”x18”). It has a solid woven base. Its woven solid halfway up, then brought in towards the top leaving opening for handles. Many weaving techniques will be taught. Color choices will be available. You will leave class with a finished basket to impress your family and friends! This is a beginner friendly basket weaving class.

name: Summer Weekly Adult: The Supposed Object with Rebecca Carter
description:
8-week adult art course
Wednesday evenings, June 4 - July 23, 6:30-9:30pm
Instructor: Rebecca Carter

This course is an opportunity to develop conceptual depth and idea generation while experimenting with a variety of materials in 2 and 3 dimensions. Students will choose one object to examine and work with for the entire session. Each week we will approach art making and thinking through a different methodology, with emphasis on basic skills, materials, techniques, and concept development. Reading about and looking at contemporary art will inform our activities. The course is open to all levels; anyone with an open mind and a desire for serious play is welcome to attend.

A supply list will be provided at the first class, and all supplies will be available at Oil and Cotton to students at a 20% discount.

name: June 13 Memory Jugs with Bruce Lee Webb
description:
Friday, June 13, 6:30-9pm
Memory Jugs with Bruce Lee Webb

n this workshop students will learn the history and origin of the folk art tradition of making Memory Jugs. Bruce, owner of the amazing Webb Gallery in Waxahachie, began collecting and researching Memory jugs 25 years ago, finding the curious crazy textures and tactile qualities alluring.

Memory Jugs were made in many cultures, but in Victorian times, when amplified mourning traditions took root, they became a folk art phenomenon. Memory jugs were often found in Victorian parlors along side hair weavings in shadow boxes. In African American cemeteries in the Southern United States, examples have been found on graves. Some jugs had a hole made in the jug to render it useless and to "release the spirit from haunting the jug" which was then covered with various small articles of a loved one. A memory jug empties Grandpas trinket drawer and elevates the myriad of objects to art for the fireplace mantel. They are objects of sentimentality with the power to evoke memories.

In the workshop students will be provided "borrowed memories" and will work on a Mason jar. Bruce will provide each student with a mason jar, plaster putty, paint and trinkets and pottery shards for their memory jar. Students are encouraged to bring their own jug or other item they want to cover as well as any memorable items for their jar.

www.webbartgallery.com

name: June 21 Small New England Tote (lunch pail)
description: Master weaver Jan Schmidt will take you through the "ins and outs" of weaving your very own basket from start to finish. This sweet little tote is perfect for carrying your lunch are as a catch all. This is a very strong basket using shaker tape that wraps all the way around the bottom. Shaping is most important in the weaving of this basket. A variety of colors will be available.

name: June 28 Marbling Paper and Fabric
description:
Saturday,  June 28, 10am-12pm
Instructor: Shannon Driscoll

Marbling is an ancient technique used to embellish paper and fabric with swirls of color. This is a fun class that allows students to be creative without needing art experience. Colors are floated on a gel-like bath and transferred to paper and fabric surfaces.

Students will learn:
-chemistry and how to coat papers and surface with an alum mordant -how to make a Carrageenan size -how mix and test a variety of paints with gall -to make a splatter brush and other marbling tools from house hold items -how to manipulate the floating paints to create magical patterns of color Leave class with at least 10 sheets of marbled paper and 2 fabric samples.

name: July 19 Bulb Basket
description:
Students will learn an open weave pattern and make a functional bulb basket in one class day. The basket is woven in the round in your lap and takes on a beautiful organic shape. This is a wonderful beginning level basket weaving class, all levels are welcome.

The basket begins by making a star pattern of reeds that are held in place with a weight. Then a small thin reed is woven around and around to form the bulbous body of the basket. A pretty leather strap is added so that the basket can hang from a door knob or hook.

name: Leather Crafts Birthday Party
description:
Leather Crafts - Cuff Bracelet, Mini Field Pouch or Purse
Ages 6 - Adult
$150 for 90 minutes, or $200 for two hours
Cuff or Mini Pouch: $15 per person
Purse: $20 per person

Sift through beautiful cut leather shapes and colors to design your original wearable art. Combine natural leather neutrals and dyed brights to finish a stylish leather cuff bracelet or functional leather pouch or purse. Color schemes, compositional design, simple stitchery and collage techniques will be learned.

Rental fee is $100 per hour in addition to a material fee per child (see below). A $200 deposit is required to hold the date (this will be applied to your final balance to cover hourly fee). Families are welcome to decorate our space and bring food and gifts. Custom projects are available. Our calendar fills up quickly, early booking is recommended. Oil and Cotton also creates gift bags for guests filled with art and craft supplies, email or call us for more information.

name: Watercolor and Nature Birthday Package
description:
Watercolor and Nature
Ages 2 - Adult
$150 for 1.5 hours plus $10 per person

Explore the beauty of watercolor through the work of artists such as Georgia O'Keeffe. Children learn watercolor techniques (wet on wet, dry brush, resist, color mixing, glazing) and create a nature inspired a painting on watercolor paper. Children are introduced to a brief history of Georgia O'Keeffe and her love of the southwestern landscape. Learn painting techniques including color mixing and proper brush care while being encouraged to have fun with process and paint!

Rental fee is $100 per hour in addition to a material fee per child (see below). A $200 deposit is required to hold the date (this will be applied to your final balance to cover hourly fee). Families are welcome to decorate our space and bring food and gifts. Custom projects are available. Our calendar fills up quickly, early booking is recommended. Oil and Cotton also creates gift bags for guests filled with art and craft supplies, email or call us for more information.

name: Colorful Collage Birthday Party Package
description:
Collage with Eric Carle
Ages 3 – Adult
$200 for 2 hours, $10 per person

One of our favorite books is the Very Hungry Caterpillar written and illustrated by Eric Carle.  Like Mr. Carle, Children will use a variety of hand painted and colored papers to make an animal or insect collage. Teachers will demonstrated paper tearing, cutting and gluing techniques. 

Rental fee is $100 per hour in addition to a material fee per child (see below). A $200 deposit is required to hold the date (this will be applied to your final balance to cover hourly fee). Families are welcome to decorate our space and bring food and gifts. Custom projects are available. Our calendar fills up quickly, early booking is recommended. Oil and Cotton also creates gift bags for guests filled with art and craft supplies, email or call us for more information.

name: Painted Canvas Birthday Party Package
description:
Painted Canvas
Ages 5 - Adult
$200 for 2 Hours, $15 per person

Our talented teachers lead individuals step by step as they paint a stretched canvas inspired by artists ranging from Vincent Van Gogh to Wayne Thiebaud. Younger children may choose abstract paintings inspired by Jackson Pollock or Mark Rothko. If starry nights, sweets, or color fields are not your child's favorite subject matter we can help you choose other painting inspiration, perhaps a bluebonnet covered field inspired by our own native landscape or a color wheel that explores the magic of the rainbow. 

Children are introduced to a brief history of an artist and learn about art mediums and painting techniques including color mixing and proper brush care. Most of all they are encouraged, praised, and have fun with process and paint!

Rental fee is $100 per hour in addition to a material fee per child (see below). A $200 deposit is required to hold the date (this will be applied to your final balance to cover hourly fee). Families are welcome to decorate our space and bring food and gifts. Custom projects are available. Our calendar fills up quickly, early booking is recommended. Oil and Cotton also creates gift bags for guests filled with art and craft supplies, email or call us for more information.

name: Dream Catcher Birthday Package
description:
Dream Catchers
Ages 8 - Adult
$200 for 2 hours, $15 per person

Your daydreamer will learn to wrap a hoop in colorful papers and weave a magical web embellished with feathers and beads. Children are introduced to the history of the dream catcher and basic weaving. It is recommended that children know how to tie knots.

Rental fee is $100 per hour in addition to a material fee per child (see below). A $200 deposit is required to hold the date (this will be applied to your final balance to cover hourly fee). Families are welcome to decorate our space and bring food and gifts. Custom projects are available. Our calendar fills up quickly, early booking is recommended. Oil and Cotton also creates gift bags for guests filled with art and craft supplies, email or call us for more information.

name: Adult Craft Party
description:
Gather your best friends for an afternoon or night of fun. Enjoy our lovely space as you make something unique, drink, eat, and chat. Our craft parties are perfect for birthdays, bridal showers, work retreats, or just an excuse to get together. Choose from our roster of beautiful projects, have us custom design something for you, or allow us to arrange a private class with one of our fabulous workshop teachers (price varies).

Projects available:
Dream Catcher
Leather mask
Leather field journal
Pajaki (paper chandelier - group project)
Still Life Painting on Canvas
Botanical Collage
Bottle Cutting (1 kit included. Purchase additional kits per 4 people)


Located at Tyler & Davis, we are easy to access from major highways and within blocks of Dallas' best restaurants. Parking is available in our Davis lot as well as along 7th Street. We also have a list of local recommended floral, cake, catering, and entertainment services. Out of town guests may stay at the nearby Belmont Hotel with an Oil and Cotton discount.

Please contact Shannon at 214.942.0474 or info@oilandcotton.com with questions and to secure your private event date and time.

options.name: Two-hour party for up to 10 guests

name: Birthday Party Deposit - General
description:
Rental fee is $100 per hour in addition to a material fee per child . A $200 deposit is required to hold the date (this will be applied to your final balance to cover hourly fee). 

Families are welcome to decorate our space and bring food and gifts. Custom projects are available. Our calendar fills up quickly, early booking is recommended. Oil and Cotton also creates gift bags for guests filled with art and craft supplies, email or call us for more information.

name: Space Rental
description:
We offer a beautiful creative space to host your next personal or professional event. Located at Tyler & Davis, we are easy to access from major highways and within blocks of Dallas' best restaurants, bars, and venues. 
Our 900 square foot event space has lovely natural light, exposed brick, tin ceilings, and an antique piano. Tables and chairs are available for up to forty guests, as well as rustic linens of muslin, burlap and leather. Oil and Cotton can create custom takeaways, centerpieces, and decoration. We also have a list of local recommended floral, cake, catering, and entertainment services. Out of town guests may stay at the nearby Belmont Hotel with an Oil and Cotton discount.

Past events have included art exhibitions, corporate retreats, bridal showers, birthday parties, CD release party, piano recitals, a surprise wine tasting, a pop-up shop, film screenings, a dance party, and a stationary bike race! We challenge you to stump us.
Please contact us at 214.942.0474 or info@oilandcotton.com with questions and to secure your event date and time.

name: Custom Kids Birthday Party
description:
Kids love art! Host your child's birthday party in style at Oil and Cotton. Voted Best Children's Art Class in Dallas by D Magazine, our teaching staff of artists is friendly, professional and fun. The studio provides an atmosphere that is unique and exciting both for kids and their parents. We offer a range of age-appropriate party projects and can custom design projects to fit your theme. Art time lasts about an hour, leaving you party time for cake, presents & games.

For ages 2-5: Try a Creative Stations party. Kids explore collage, drawing and craft projects set up in stations around the room. Your guide will engage little ones in the process, lead a storytime and sing-along, as well as assist you with party set up & clean up.

For ages 5+: Pick your own art class! One of our awesome teachers will lead you and your guests in a one-hour art project to take home. Choose from a canvas painting, expert watercolor, Texas embroidery, autograph book, friendship jewelry, cartoon illustration, clay sculpture, paper bouquet, or dream catcher.

Located at Tyler & Davis, we are easy to access from major highways and within blocks of Dallas' best restaurants. Parking is available in our Davis lot as well as along 7th Street. 

Your party craft makes a sweet takeaway, and some generous parents add on with art supplies from our store, available to the host at 25% off. Add on killer goodie bags designed just for you! Oil and Cotton can also create custom takeaways, centerpieces, and decoration, or you are welcome to bring your own. We also have a list of local recommended floral, cake, catering, and entertainment services. Out of town guests may stay at the nearby Belmont Hotel with an Oil and Cotton discount.

Contact us at 214.942.0474 or info@oilandcotton.com with questions and to secure your party date and time.

name: Oil and Cotton Gift Certificate
description:
The perfect last minute solution!

Gift certificates are redeemable for weekly classes, workshops, or for use in our retail boutique. Not redeemable for cash. Expires one year from date of purchase.

Sold in multiples of $25.

We will email you a numbered gift certificate PDF to print out and give to your creative (or soon to be) loved ones!

name: Coming soon...Fall Adult Drawing: Construction and Representation
description:
Fall 2014... Details TBD

Construction and Representation
WEEKLY ART CLASS
11-week series for Adults
Instructor: Kyle Hobratschk
Price: $330 + $60 supply fee

We will begin building our subject matter with landscapes from red brick and sand to nestle small constructions made from mat board and white paint that reference architectural forms and functions both primitively and modernly.  Proportion, variance, representation and urban planning will propel this work through conversation, history and text from sources like 19th Century engravings of ancient ruins and A Pattern Language.   This simulated environment will highlight everyday visual phenomenon in light, shadow, reflection and color temperature for us to represent in graphite, ink and watercolor wash, gesso, collage and printmaking in Kyle’s studio.  Each of these mediums will be investigated and layered thoroughly to build a rich, concentrated body of work.  

This course is designed to teach the mechanics of drawing and rendering of objects in space through multiple approaches and levels of abstraction possible only by medium-specific exploration.  This extended, 11-week course enables students to learn and work with quality focus and investment to return substantial ability.

Teens are encouraged to use this course to build a meaningful portfolio of quality work. Adults of beginner and advanced levels will  learn or refresh fluency in rendering and medium usage.

name: Coming soon... Sew an Apron
description:
Date & Time TBD
Instructor: Jesse Bartlett

Choose your favorite colors and cotton fabrics to create this oh-sew-fabulous apron, perfect for holiday cooking or as a handmade gift!  Apron details include a pocket, learning how to make a gathering stitch, and bias-tape application. A supply list and apron pattern will be emailed to you when you sign up for the class.  Machine sewing experience is required for this class.  No sewing experience?  No problem!  Sign up for a private lesson with the instructor, Jesse Bartlett. Email or call to learn more about private instruction. 

About the Instructor:
Jesse Bartlett is a professional seamstress and art teacher from Oak Cliff, Texas. Learn more about her at www.sewjesse.com.

*Machine rentals: $5 (need to let us know beforehand because we have a limited number of machines available)
Max students: 6 adults

name: Coming soon...Fall Teen Drawing: Construction and Representation with Kyle Hobratschk
description:
Currently in session... we will repeat it next year!

Construction and Representation
WEEKLY ART CLASS
11-week series for Teens (5:30-7pm)
Wednesdays, September 4 - November 13
Instructor: Kyle Hobratschk
Price: $275 + $60 supply fee

We will begin building our subject matter with landscapes from red brick and sand to nestle small constructions made from mat board and white paint that reference architectural forms and functions both primitively and modernly.  Proportion, variance, representation and urban planning will propel this work through conversation, history and text from sources like 19th Century engravings of ancient ruins and A Pattern Language.   This simulated environment will highlight everyday visual phenomenon in light, shadow, reflection and color temperature for us to represent in graphite, ink and watercolor wash, gesso, collage and printmaking in Kyle’s studio.  Each of these mediums will be investigated and layered thoroughly to build a rich, concentrated body of work.  

This course is designed to teach the mechanics of drawing and rendering of objects in space through multiple approaches and levels of abstraction possible only by medium-specific exploration.  This extended, 11-week course enables students to learn and work with quality focus and investment to return substantial ability.

Teens are encouraged to use this course to build a meaningful portfolio of quality work. Adults of beginner and advanced levels will  learn or refresh fluency in rendering and medium usage.

name: Coming soon... Triangle Loom Weaving with June Covington
description:
Date & Time TBD
Instructor: June Covington 
Price: $50

In this introductory class students will begin weaving on a small wooden frame triangle loom using traditional methods and materials. Students will learn terms and skills used in frame-loom weaving and will explore  plain weave, tension, joining, tying-up, and warping the loom. Come join this awesome class where craft meets the beautiful form of the TRIANGLE!

name: Coming Soon... Needle Felting Brittany Harris
description:
Date & Time TBD
Instructor: Brittany Harris

Students will explore the 2D and 3D possibilities of the needle felting technique. Needle felting is a popular fiber art that creates felt without the use of water. Special needles that are used in industrial felting machines are used by the artist as a sculpting tool. Notches along the shaft of the needle grab the top layer of fibers and tangle them with the inner layers of fibers as the needle enters the wool. Since these notches face down towards the tip of the needle, they do not pull the fibers out as the needle exits the wool. Once tangled and compressed using the needle, the felt can be strong and used for creating jewelry or sculpture. Using a single needle or a small group of needles (2-5) in a hand-held tool, fine details can be achieved using this technique. Students will leave class with a complete needle felting kit to continue experimenting and and felting at home.

Materials included:
-Sponge
-Set of 3 needles
-Wool Roving

name: Coming soon...Shibori with Lizzy Wetzel
description:
Some Sunday, 11am-2pm
Instructor: Lizzy Wetzel

Shibori is a Japanese term for several methods of dyeing cloth with a pattern by binding, stitching, folding, twisting, compressing it, or capping. In this workshop, students will mix an indigo vat, stitch and clip, and dye an infinity scarf, a simple and elegant accessory to keep you warm when you visit us at the DMA this summer. Artist Lizzy Wetzel﻿ is visiting from her digs in Marfa, Texas to share the story of Shibori with you. Register now for the magic.

name: Coming soon...Kaleidoscope with Rachel Rushing
description:
Date & Time TBA
Instructor: Rachel Rushing

Kaleidoscope is derived from Ancient Greek, meaning "observer of beautiful forms". Invented in 1816 by Sir David Brewster, Kaleidoscopes are optical instruments that combine science and beauty to create brilliantly reflective patterns. 

While exploring various styles, learn to construct your own kaleidoscope from archival bookmaking materials and slide film. Students are welcome and encouraged to bring their own 2x2 in. slides and breathe new life into old imagery. Materials include: Davey board, bookcloth, decorative papers, slides, and mirrors.

This class is limited to eight students; please register in advance to secure a space.

name: Coming soon... Photography: Introduction to Wet-plate Collodion, Tintypes with Ginger Berry
description:
Saturday,TBD, 10-4pm
Introduction: Ginger Berry
 
The Tintype is a positive image on a metal plate. The process is similar to daguerreotypes and ambrotypes, which were positive images on glass that could only be seen if you placed a background such as black velvet behind them, otherwise they were negatives. Participants will be introduced to the fundamentals of the wet-plate collodion process. Through a fully-immersive, hands-on, approach, they will uncover the techniques and knowledge necessary to produce their very own, unique, tintypes-- uncovering one of the most signiﬁcant advancements in the history photography. All levels are welcome, no darkroom experience needed.

Goals 
This workshop aims to achieve the following: 
•To provide each student with basic knowledge of the wet-plate collodion process. 
•Give the participants an opportunity to learn the technique in a hands-on environment. 
•Leave the workshop with at least three (3) ﬁnished images. 

Curriculum 
The class will have a practical, hands-on, approach while also covering basic (and brief) but necessary topics such as history of the process, chemistry and equipment and safety. * 

*Advanced registration is encouraged.

name: Coming soon... Believing Your Own Hype: Manifesto Writing for Not Necessarily Angry Individuals
description:
Friday, Date TBA, 6:30-9:30
Instructor: Joe Milazzo

Do you sometimes find it difficult to say exactly what you mean? Do you often feel that, as soon as an idea is expressed in words, it loses much of its power and significance? Are you looking for ways to sharpen and more completely organize your thoughts on a subject that really matters to you? If so, you might consider writing a manifesto. In this intensive workshop, we will examine the manifesto as a literary genre, with special emphasis on art manifestos. We will look at some model texts and discuss how these manifestos present their arguments and approach the question of audience. We will also address our attention to a series of exercises designed to facilitate the composition of our own manifestos, with further discussion of specific applications to be made from this experience. (e.g., That artist's statement really giving you trouble? What if your first draft took the form of a manifesto?) Finally, we will stage a public—on the street-corner, complete with megaphone—reading of the manifestos that we have written.

*BYOB and food. Make an evening out of it, bring a friend and a classroom picnic.

About the instructor: Joe Milazzo is the author of The Terraces (Das Arquibancadas) (Little Red Leaves Textile Series, 2012), and has also published poetry, fiction and essays in a wide variety of publications, including The Dallas Morning News, The Collagist, H_NGM_N, Vinyl Poetry, and Black Clock. In addition to teaching creative writing and literature at various institutions and community centers across Dallas-Fort Worth, Joe is also co-founder of the interdisciplinary arts organization Strophe, co-editor of the online journal [out of nothing], and proprietor of Imipolex Press. A Dallas native, Joe holds an MFA in Writing from the California Institute of the Arts. You can learn more about Joe, his teaching, his publications and his current activities by visiting his personal website: http://www.slowstudies.net/jmilazzo.

name: Coming Soon...Painting: Live Portraiture with Anna Membrino
description:
Weekender Workshop 
Saturday, 10-4pm
Sunday, 1-4pm
Instructor: Anna Membrino

In this workshop students will begin to study the art of portraiture. After examining the structure of the skull and the proportions of a face, students will begin to paint from a live model.  Over the course of two days students will practice the drawing of the head, the mixing of skin tones, and the construction through paint of a convincing portrait. 

All skill levels are encouraged and welcomed!

Supply Kit Includes:
Set of brushes
Canvas
6 M. Graham acrylic tubes
($100 value)

Learn more about Anna at her website www.annamembrino.com

name: Coming soon...Painting Abstracted Nature with Anna Membrino
description:
Date & Time TBA
3-week workshop
Instructor: Anna Membrino

Abstracted Nature: In this three night workshop students will explore the complexities of natural objects. Working from fruits, plants, rocks, and bones, we will draw and paint a detailed section of these relatively small objects. By cropping in closely on our subject matter the paintings will remain in the anonymous, emotive world of abstraction.

Students will paint several small studies of their subject before creating a final piece.

Supply Kit Includes:
2 oz. tubes of M. Graham acrylic in Prussian Blue, Cadmium Red, Cadmium Yellow, Raw Sienna, Dioxazine Purple, Titanium White
Acrylic brush set
12x12 or 12x16 cradled wood panel surface


Learn more about Anna at her beautiful website, 
www.annamembrino.com

name: Coming soon...Watercolor Series with Kyle Hobratschk
description:
Coming soon...
4 Week Series | Date TBA | Saturdays | 10am-2pm

Enroll in this workshop to learn more about the sensitive relationship between watercolor, the brush, and paper.  We will discuss essential techniques like creating variegated washes and full-bodied strokes, the hallmarks of watercolor, to simply define complex shapes and objects from reality.  You will learn to use one large brush exclusively for a range of strokes both large and small, and how to mix color with the knowledge of pigment types and complex color theory.  

We will cover methods for achieving structure in your paintings by combining pencil and ink with the fluid energy of watercolor.  Still lifes composed with ordinary and unusual objects will stimulate our artwork, while fascinating history about pigments and their use today will complement our studio time.

A supply list will be given at the first class. Absolute beginners kits ($100) as well as supplemental supplies will be available at a student discount in our shop. The recommended supply list is composed of a careful selection of brushes and pigment rich, artist-quality paints instead of student-grade supplies.

Payment plans are available based on financial need.

This class is limited to 8 students, please register in advance.

Instructor: Kyle Hobratschk
www.kylehobratschk.com
